ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to communicate succinctly and compellingly.
This course helped me learn how to develop critical and compelling arguments. It definitely spanned a large set of global health topics, and tried to get at the question of how we can address issues.

I learned how to practically think about effective health-policy making and how to center equity at the forefront of public health decisions. I was also exposed to many different perspectives on how to best approach complicated health issues, and acquired a broader appreciation for the level of care, detail and planning that goes into ensuring that no one is left behind when drafting public health policies, and that interventions don't have collateral effects that are worse than the problems that we are aiming to solve.
I learned about global health theories and frameworks and different case studies
Writing critical analyses that are brief and communicate the most important issues on our readings. Also learned a lot about communicating science and drafting global health policy.

This course taught me valuable skills in synthesizing large amounts of the dense information on health policy into short, impactful 2 page reports. The ability to distill tens of pages of academic journal writing into a brief message is one of the most important skills needed in public health communication and the presentation assignment and writing prompts required of students in this course granted me valuable practice with these techniques, helping to build my analytical skills.

I learned about a variety of topics in global health, including global clinical trial and research ethics, the political economy of health, the impacts of immigration policies on health, and many more. I gained a better understanding of how policy is designed and how considerations of equity figure in to influencing policy decisions. The readings in the course consist of policy recommendations, social science academic articles, news articles, etc. so there is a wide range of content to learn from.
To really question global health as a structure and how interventions and frameworks can be challenged. How to ask the right questions when wanting to help someone and what equity looks like.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course really pushes you to form your own opinions, illustrate them and critique your illustrations in less than 2 pages which is a huge feat for someone used to rambling. The readings were relevant and generally thought provoking. Classroom discussions however sometimes felt a little dull, although this could just be because of Zoom. It would be nice if Prof. PB pushed people to be more vocal/drew on submitted critical analyses to encourage participation.

This course was one of the best I have taken during my time at Yale. The breadth and depth of material that we covered, the variety of topics that Professor PB brought to conversation in class, and the engagement of everyone in the seminar with the discussions made it such an exciting, interesting, enlightening and engaging learning experience!

Professor PB was the absolute highlight of this course. Our discussions were interesting and she encouraged participation with her facilitation. Her implementation of podcasts, videos and guest speakers in addition to readings, discussions and class presentations made class enjoyable.
Strengths  the reading assignments were incredibly engaging, important, and fascinating. This course helped me build my skills in reading academic papers in a time efficient manner and note taking.

I think the course could benefit from more discussion into how policy decisions/policy itself is drafted and made in global health contexts. Doing so could provide opportunities to see how equity is (or isn't) considered in enacted policies, as well as think about ways to implement equity into health focused policy. In terms of logistics, it was nice to have options over which readings to complete, but I think a core set each week with optional supplements could help with facilitating discussion throughout class sessions. The assignment schedule was structured well and allowed for flexibility while ensuring that students did not fall behind.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The weekly  presentations were a good way to summarise the readings. Zoom backgrounds fuelled conversation.
Everything worked really well. Professor PB's encouragement of fun Zoom backgrounds also made our meetings very amusing :)
videos, podcasts, guest speakers on zoom

Success: The changes to the final assignment were very considerate and allowed for a more realistic and engaging project given the circumstances. I honestly feel like a policy brief/Op-Ed is the way to go!
Professor PB did an excellent job trying to facilitate an engaging, inclusive, and lively seminar format (even over Zoom) by asking us to unmute ourselves when the class was opened up for discussion.

Ending classes a bit earlier than the full class period was extremely helpful for preventing burn out, especially towards the end of the term when the weather improved and being outside/not looking on a screen was great for mental & physical health.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. If your writing resembles long rambling, you need Prof. PB's critical analyses in your life.
Absolutely!!!! It broadened my perspective on Global Health equity and policy in truly indescribable ways.

YES. If you have the opportunity to take this course with Prof PB, DO IT! She is so amazing and kind and compassionate. Especially during the pandemic, she made class such an enjoyable and comfortable space. This class is hard, but Professor PB will push you to think and reflect critically. I feel like I learned a ton of valuable information and writing skills from this class.
ABSOLUTELY! Professor Panter-Brick is just so incredible and she really trains you to be an effective writer on issues of global health.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any student interested in global health (and even those students looking for a fun social science and writing credit). I learned so much in this class and will take the analytical writing skills I developed in this seminar with me in my future courses.

I would! Professor Panter-Brick is wonderful and truly cares about her students and their learning. She was more than willing to implement changes to the syllabus that the class suggested and was extremely accommodating. Beyond the assigned readings, Prof PB offers so much from her experiences working in global health and never shies away from sharing or speaking to topics students are interested in.
I would strongly recommend this course to people who are new to global health, so primarily to sophomores in the GHS program. As a junior in GHS, not much of the content was too new.
Yes! only if it's taught by Professor Panter-Brick
